title: Consecutive Integers with Large Prime Divisors
description: Let k(n) be the maximal k such that there exists m ≤ n where each of m+1,...,m+k is divisible by at least one prime > k. Estimate k(n). Known bounds: exp(c√(log n log log n)) ≤ k(n) ≤ (1+o(1))√n.

meta.author: Paul Erdős, Terence Tao, Tang
originalContributions: Definition of largest prime factor (lpf) function
Definition of IsValidInterval for consecutive integers
Formalization of the k(n) function via supremum
Axiomatization of Erdős's original lower bound (1965)
Axiomatization of Tang's improved lower bound
Formalization of Tao's pigeonhole argument sketch
Formalization of smooth numbers and their connection

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this problem in 1965 at a symposium on extremal problems in number theory. The problem asks about the longest intervals where all integers have a 'large' prime factor. Tao provided the first non-trivial upper bound via a simple pigeonhole argument, while Tang improved Erdős's original lower bound.
overview.problemStatement: Let k(n) be the maximal k such that there exists m ≤ n where each of m+1, ..., m+k is divisible by at least one prime greater than k. Estimate k(n).
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines the k(n) function, establishes basic properties like monotonicity, then axiomatizes the known bounds: Tang's lower bound exp((1/√2-o(1))√(log n log log n)) and Tao's upper bound (1+o(1))√n. The conjecture k(n) = o(n^ε) remains open.
keyInsights: k(n) measures the longest 'large prime factor' interval below n
Lower bound uses sieve methods to avoid small primes
Upper bound uses pigeonhole: if k > √n, some small prime divides two nearby integers
The gap between bounds is enormous (subpolynomial vs polynomial)
Connection to smooth numbers: non-smooth integers avoid small prime factors

sections.title: Part I: Basic Definitions
sections.summary: Defines largest prime factor lpf(n) and HasLargePrimeFactor predicate.

sections.title: Part II: The k(n) Function
sections.summary: Defines IsValidInterval and the k_func(n) as supremum of valid interval lengths.

sections.title: Part III: Basic Properties
sections.summary: Monotonicity, positivity, and small values of k(n).

sections.title: Part V: Tang's Improved Lower Bound
sections.summary: Axiomatizes k(n) ≥ exp((1/√2-o(1))√(log n log log n)).

sections.title: Part VI: Tao's Upper Bound
sections.summary: Axiomatizes k(n) ≤ (1+o(1))√n with pigeonhole argument sketch.

sections.title: Part VII: Erdős's Conjecture
sections.summary: Formalizes conjecture k(n) = o(n^ε) for all ε > 0 (OPEN).

sections.title: Part VIII: The Gap Between Bounds
sections.summary: Discusses the enormous gap: subpolynomial vs √n.

sections.title: Part IX: Smooth Numbers Connection
sections.summary: Reformulates k(n) in terms of non-smooth number intervals.

sections.title: Part X: Summary
sections.summary: Problem solved for bounds, conjecture remains open.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #962 asks for estimates of k(n), the longest interval below n where all integers have a large prime factor. Tang's lower bound and Tao's upper bound bracket k(n), but the gap is enormous. Erdős's conjecture that k(n) = o(n^ε) remains open.
conclusion.implications: The problem connects prime distribution with divisibility patterns of consecutive integers. Resolution would illuminate how primes are distributed relative to intervals of integers.
openQuestions: Is k(n) = o(n^ε) for all ε > 0? (Erdős's conjecture)
Can the gap between √(log n log log n) and √n be closed?
What is the true order of magnitude of k(n)?
